labels.name: Name
labels.filter_intersection: Show only segments with all filtered runners

messages.drag_drop: Drag and drop files here to import or choose above.
messages.no_split_times: No split times available for this result list.
messages.top_100_shown: Showing top 100 runners only (segment limited for performance)
messages.select_analysis_type_and_configure: Select an analysis type and configure its scope to get started.
messages.mri_description: The Mental Resilience Index (MRI) measures how runners react mentally after making navigation mistakes.
messages.split_time_description: Analyze split times and performance across segments.
messages.split_time_table_description: Classic Winsplits-style table with runners in rows and controls in columns.
messages.anomaly_detection_description: Detect statistical anomalies that may indicate anomaly or course shortcuts.
messages.hanging_detection_description: Detect when runners follow faster runners (bus drivers) and achieve significantly better performance than their baseline.
messages.ai_explanation: The Anomalies Index (AI) compares a runner's actual performance to their expected performance on a specific segment.
messages.ai_calculation_detail: AI values significantly below 1.0 may indicate unusually fast times.
messages.high_suspicion_explanation: AI < 0.30 and PI < 0.30 - high likelihood of anomaly: â‰¥70% faster than top-3 and own baseline.
messages.moderate_suspicion_explanation: AI < 0.45 and PI < 0.45 - moderate likelihood of anomaly: â‰¥55% faster than top-3 and own baseline.
messages.no_suspicion_explanation: AI â‰¥ 0.45 or PI â‰¥ 0.45 - unlikely to be anomalous: performance within expected range.
messages.no_data_explanation: Insufficient data for reliable analysis of this segment.
messages.hi_explanation: The Hanging Index (HI) measures whether a runner performed significantly better on a segment than their normal baseline when following another runner.
messages.hi_calculation_detail: HI values â‰¤ 0.85 indicate at least 15% improvement compared to the runner's normal performance, suggesting they may have benefited from following a faster runner.
messages.hanging_detection_criteria: A segment is classified as 'hanging' when all three criteria are met:
messages.criteria_temporal_proximity: Temporal Proximity: The passenger punched â‰¤30 seconds after the bus driver
messages.criteria_performance_hierarchy: Performance Hierarchy: The bus driver was faster (lower PI) on that segment
messages.criteria_performance_improvement: Performance Improvement: The passenger achieved â‰¥15% better than their normal baseline (HI â‰¤ 0.85)
messages.high_hanging_explanation: â‰¥3 hanging segments OR â‰¥30% of all segments - runner shows pattern of frequently following others
messages.moderate_hanging_explanation: 1-2 hanging segments OR <30% of segments - runner occasionally benefits from following others
messages.no_hanging_explanation: No hanging segments detected - runner maintains performance independently
messages.insufficient_data_explanation: Insufficient data for baseline (Normal PI) calculation - requires at least 3 non-mistake segments
messages.unreliable_class_warning: Some classes have fewer than 5 runners. Results may be less reliable for these classes.
messages.low_runner_count_warning: This class has fewer than 5 runners, which may affect the reliability of the analysis.
messages.no_mental_data: No mental resilience data available for this selection.
messages.mri_explanation: The Mental Resilience Index (MRI) measures how runners mentally react to navigation mistakes.
messages.mri_calculation_detail: where PI(n+1) is the Performance Index of the segment after the mistake and Normal PI is the average PI without mistakes.
messages.mri_negative: Runner reacts with panic (runs too fast)
messages.pi_explanation: The Performance Index (PI) is the ratio of the runner's time to the reference time on a segment.
messages.pi_elite: Runner was better than the reference time (median of top 3 runners)
messages.panic_explanation: Runners with MRI < -0.05 run significantly faster than normal after a mistake, risking further errors.
messages.ice_man_explanation: Runners with MRI â‰ˆ 0 (Â±0.05) maintain their normal pace despite mistakes and stay mentally stable.
messages.resigner_explanation: Runners with MRI > +0.05 slow down significantly after mistakes due to uncertainty or resignation.
messages.chain_error_explanation: Runner makes consecutive mistakes (reaction segment PI > 1.30), indicating loss of control or disorientation.
messages.average_mri_explanation: The Average MRI is the mean value of all MRI values from all mistake-reaction pairs in the event.
messages.average_mri_calculation: Avg. MRI = Sum of all MRI values / Number of all mistake-reactions
messages.average_mri_negative_detail: Runners tend overall to run too fast after mistakes (panic tendency)
messages.average_mri_neutral_detail: Runners remain stable overall despite mistakes and maintain their normal pace
messages.average_mri_positive_detail: Runners tend overall to slow down after mistakes (resignation tendency)
messages.mistake_pi_explanation: The Performance Index on the segment where the mistake occurred (PI > 1.30). Shows how much slower the runner was compared to the reference time.
messages.reaction_pi_explanation: The Performance Index on the segment immediately after the mistake. This value is compared with the Normal PI to calculate the MRI.
messages.severity_explanation: Mistakes are classified into three severity levels based on the Mistake PI:
messages.moderate_severity_explanation: PI between 1.30 and 1.50 - Minor mistake, about 30-50% slower than reference time
messages.major_severity_explanation: PI between 1.50 and 2.00 - Moderate mistake, 50-100% slower than reference time
messages.severe_severity_explanation: PI over 2.00 - Severe mistake, more than twice as slow as reference time
messages.mistake_detection_intro: A segment is considered a navigation mistake when BOTH criteria are met:
messages.mistake_detection_explanation: The median difference is the runner's 'normalized performance'. The 30-second threshold prevents small pace variations on short segments from being incorrectly identified as mistakes.
messages.pi_reference_time_note: Reference time = Average of top 3 times (more robust than single best time)

errors.conflict: Requested change results in a conflict. {name}, {message}

splitTimeTable.title: Split Time Table
splitTimeTable.unreliableDataWarning: Warning: Less than 5 runners - statistical analysis may not be reliable.
splitTimeTable.noData: No data available. Please select a class or course.

help.tableStructureText: The table displays split times for each runner at every control. On the left are frozen columns (Position, Runner Name, Total Time, Time Behind), on the right are control columns. Each control cell contains two lines:
help.cumulativeTimeDesc: Time from start to this control (with position)
help.segmentTimeDesc: Time from previous control to this control (with position)
help.bestTimesText: Times and positions in bold (in light mode) or in bold and amber color (in dark mode) indicate the best time at that control. Important: For cumulative times, only competing runners are considered (not competing runners excluded), for segment times all runners including not competing are considered.
help.notCompetingRunnersText: Not competing runners are marked with (NC) or (AK) after their name. They receive no overall position and are sorted after regular competitors. However, their segment times are considered when determining best segment times.
help.errorHighlightingText: Cells are colored when the runner had a significant time loss at this control. The color indicates the severity:
help.errorCalculationText: Error detection is based on PI comparison (Performance Index): A segment is marked as an error when the runner's segment-PI is significantly worse than their Normal-PI (average performance level). The color is based on the magnitude of the deviation.

about.title: About Resulter
about.description: Resulter is an innovative web application for orienteering enthusiasts and organizers of orienteering competitions.
about.features: Content: Event list with optional result lists, download of individual certificates for competitors, calculations of cup and ranking list points.
about.futurePlans: Future expansions are planned to include different analysis of split times.
about.contact: For inquiries, please email us at

overview.heading: Overview
overview.text: The statistics show a summary of all participations in the North-East Ranking (NOR). It includes both scoring and non-scoring starts.

overallStats.heading: Overall Statistics
overallStats.totalRunners: Total number of different persons who participated in at least one competition.
overallStats.totalOrganisations: Number of different clubs whose members participated.
overallStats.totalStarts: Total number of all starts (including non-scoring starts). In brackets: number and percentage of non-scoring starts.
overallStats.runnersPerOrganisation: Average number of runners per club (total runners Ã· number of clubs).
overallStats.startsPerOrganisation: Average number of starts per club (total starts Ã· number of clubs). In brackets: average non-scoring starts per club.
overallStats.startsPerRunner: Average number of starts per runner (total starts Ã· number of runners). In brackets: average non-scoring starts per runner.

organisationStats.heading: Statistics by Club
organisationStats.intro: The table shows detailed statistics for each participating club, sorted by number of runners (descending).
organisationStats.runners: Number of orienteers from this club (number of different persons).
organisationStats.starts: Total number of all starts from this club (scoring and non-scoring).
organisationStats.nonScoring: Number of non-scoring starts. This includes races with status such as DNF (did not finish), disqualification, missing punch, etc.
organisationStats.startsPerRunner: Average number of starts per runner of the club (Starts Ã· Runners).
organisationStats.nonScoringPerRunner: Average number of non-scoring starts per runner (N/S Ã· Runners).
organisationStats.nonScoringRatio: Percentage of non-scoring starts out of all starts (N/S Ã· Starts Ã— 100%).

nonScoringExplanation.heading: What does "non-scoring" (N/S) mean?
nonScoringExplanation.intro: Non-scoring starts are participations that do not count towards the points scoring. These include:
nonScoringExplanation.missingPunch: Control not punched or incorrectly punched
nonScoringExplanation.note: These starts are counted to capture actual participation activity, but do not count towards the NOR point scoring.

calculationNote.title: ðŸ“Š Calculation Note
calculationNote.text: The statistics only consider runners and starts that meet the NOR criteria (e.g., club membership in the NOR organisation). All average values are rounded to two decimal places.
